awd_titl_txt: IRNC-SP: Sustainable Data-Handling and Analysis Methodologies for the IRNC Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Measurement of operational Internet infrastructure involves navigating more complex and interconnected dimensions (logistical, financial, methodological, technical, legal, and ethical) than measurement in most scientific disciplines.  These challenges impede the collection, coordination, curation, and sharing of data sets to support network architectural, engineering, security, and operations research.

This project will make three contributions to the IRNC community's measurement efforts: hosting structured discussions of how to most effectively share IRNC data and statistics; adapting exiting traffic and topology measurement technologies for IRNC community needs based on the resulting feedback; and applying two innovations in data stewardship to IRNC measurements. The measurement software improvements will include support for emerging IPv6 and DNSSEC, anonymization and aggregation for privacy protection, and data formats used by the majority of the IRNC operators, such as netflow output from routers.  It will also (optionally) install, deploy, and manage IPv6-capable active measurement nodes at each interested IRNC site.  The data stewardship contributions include: (1) experimentation with a recently developed framework for privacy-sensitive data sharing; and (2) prototyping a dissemination (reporting) format aimed at incenting broader participation in globally coordinated Internet measurements.

The project will help IRNC operators better understand their networks, and will advance the quantity and quality of data available to researchers in a number of sub-disciplines of network science. The impacts include strengthening activities in network modeling, simulation, analysis, and theoretical research, enabling the IRNC program to play a formative role in the emerging discipline of network science, and enhancing NSF's leading role in sustainable stewardship of cyberinfrastructure.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
We targeted contributions to IRNC measurement efforts on three fronts: to foster and distill discussion of how to best make IRNC data and statistics available within the community and to the public; to adapt two CAIDA measurement technologies for IRNC community needs; and to experiment with two innovations in data-handling procedures applied to existing IRNC measurements.

Over the course of the grant, we engaged the IRNC ProNet community via email, through conference calls, through presentations and face-to-face at PI Meetings, and at four IRNC-related meetings. We established a dialogue around Internet measurement techniques and policy tools that might foster broader sharing of aggregated IRNC link metadata and statistics. We summarized rough consensus of these discussions in a May 2013 technical report, "International Research Network Connections: Usage and Value Measurement'', published at: http://www.caida.org/publications/papers/2013/irnc_report-tr/.

Our improvements to two CAIDA measurement technologies (extensions to the Coralreef software suite and expansion of the Ark measurement infrastructure) were driven by feedback from IRNC ProNet PIs and gracious access to their contacts at downstream organizations such as AARNET, GEANT, ANSP, and others.

We extended the Coralreef suite with internal structures for storing IPv6 packet information, and prototyped Netflow reporting in the Coralreef Report Generator. We also had extensive interaction with IRNC ProNet PI Julio Ibarra at AMPATH to advise on specifications for the purchase, configuration, and operation of a measurement system to monitor the 10GE IRNC link between Miami and Sao Paulo, Brazil. We assisted with installation and setup of a passive monitor capable of data capture and Coralreef-based reporting.  One outcome of these interactions was the need for software that can report on layer two circuit information.

This project also supported extension of our Archipelago measurement infrastructure with host deployments via IRNC channels, including new web pages showing per-monitor connectivity and performance observed by monitors at participating IRNC sites. These reports can be found on the CAIDAweb site at http://www.caida.org/projects/ark/statistics/. The specific pages associated with monitors deployed by IRNC contacts are:

http://www.caida.org/projects/ark/statistics/bjl-gm.html

http://www.caida.org/projects/ark/statistics/sao2-br.html (raspberry pi)

http://www.caida.org/projects/ark/statistics/hnl-us.html  (raspberry pi)

http://www.caida.org/projects/ark/statistics/syd-au.html

http://www.caida.org/projects/ark/statistics/per-au.html

As described in the technical report, we see opportunities to create a single curated map of all IRNC-funded network links, ideally annotated with SNMP-based per-node or per-link traffic, that would provide high-level visibility into usage of these links, and is technically possible today assuming each IRNC site could provide its SNMP traffic data feeds to a central location, perhaps via perfSONAR. 

Notably, most ProNet project PIs are capable of providing several types of traffic-based usage reporting per link: top applications by volume; highest bandwidth flows; traffic matrix (by specific source/destination prefixes or ASes); and loss indications such as packet drops or retransmits. However, PIs have concerns regarding sharing traffic data not governed by current MOUs with partners. The most important outcome of this project may be renewed recognition that modifying MOUs as part of a future IRNC phase agreement would be required to move forward with publishing aggregated statistical repor...
por.por_txt_cntn:
We targeted contributions to IRNC measurement efforts on three fronts: to foster and distill discussion of how to best make IRNC data and statistics available within the community and to the public; to adapt two CAIDA measurement technologies for IRNC community needs; and to experiment with two innovations in data-handling procedures applied to existing IRNC measurements.

Over the course of the grant, we engaged the IRNC ProNet community via email, through conference calls, through presentations and face-to-face at PI Meetings, and at four IRNC-related meetings. We established a dialogue around Internet measurement techniques and policy tools that might foster broader sharing of aggregated IRNC link metadata and statistics. We summarized rough consensus of these discussions in a May 2013 technical report, "International Research Network Connections: Usage and Value Measurement'', published at: http://www.caida.org/publications/papers/2013/irnc_report-tr/.

Our improvements to two CAIDA measurement technologies (extensions to the Coralreef software suite and expansion of the Ark measurement infrastructure) were driven by feedback from IRNC ProNet PIs and gracious access to their contacts at downstream organizations such as AARNET, GEANT, ANSP, and others.

We extended the Coralreef suite with internal structures for storing IPv6 packet information, and prototyped Netflow reporting in the Coralreef Report Generator. We also had extensive interaction with IRNC ProNet PI Julio Ibarra at AMPATH to advise on specifications for the purchase, configuration, and operation of a measurement system to monitor the 10GE IRNC link between Miami and Sao Paulo, Brazil. We assisted with installation and setup of a passive monitor capable of data capture and Coralreef-based reporting.  One outcome of these interactions was the need for software that can report on layer two circuit information.

This project also supported extension of our Archipelago measurement infrastructure with host deployments via IRNC channels, including new web pages showing per-monitor connectivity and performance observed by monitors at participating IRNC sites. These reports can be found on the CAIDAweb site at http://www.caida.org/projects/ark/statistics/. The specific pages associated with monitors deployed by IRNC contacts are:

http://www.caida.org/projects/ark/statistics/bjl-gm.html

http://www.caida.org/projects/ark/statistics/sao2-br.html (raspberry pi)

http://www.caida.org/projects/ark/statistics/hnl-us.html  (raspberry pi)

http://www.caida.org/projects/ark/statistics/syd-au.html

http://www.caida.org/projects/ark/statistics/per-au.html

As described in the technical report, we see opportunities to create a single curated map of all IRNC-funded network links, ideally annotated with SNMP-based per-node or per-link traffic, that would provide high-level visibility into usage of these links, and is technically possible today assuming each IRNC site could provide its SNMP traffic data feeds to a central location, perhaps via perfSONAR. 

Notably, most ProNet project PIs are capable of providing several types of traffic-based usage reporting per link: top applications by volume; highest bandwidth flows; traffic matrix (by specific source/destination prefixes or ASes); and loss indications such as packet drops or retransmits. However, PIs have concerns regarding sharing traffic data not governed by current MOUs with partners. The most important outcome of this project may be renewed recognition that modifying MOUs as part of a future IRNC phase agreement would be required to move forward with publishing aggregated statistical reports. One option would be to contract with a central entity to handle advanced measurement capabilities (beyond operational monitoring such as SNMP-based) across all NSF-funded international connections, assuming both technical and policy hurdles can be cleared, speci?cally, getting consistent measurements gathered and reported, and e?ect...
